context: Their endowment by a <a1_0><b10_0>prince or monarch<b10_0/><a1_0/> and their role in training government officials made these <a0_0><b9_0>Mediterranean universities<b9_0/><a0_0/> similar to Islamic <b4_0>madrasas<b4_0/>, although madrasas were generally smaller and <a3_0><b12_0>individual teachers<b12_0/><a3_0/>, rather than the madrasa itself, granted the <b5_0>license or degree<b5_0/>. Scholars like <b6_0>Arnold H. Green and Hossein Nasr<b6_0/> have argued that starting in the <a2_0><b11_0>10th<b11_0/><a2_0/> century, some medieval Islamic <b7_0>madrasahs<b7_0/> <b8_0>became <b13_0>universities<b13_0/>.<b8_0/> George Makdisi and others, however, argue that the European university has no parallel in the medieval Islamic world. Other scholars regard the university as uniquely European in origin and characteristics.
